channel.title: Java? Rsps?
channel.description: Does runescape privite server development use all of java? Or does it only use some of java? Or can you use all of java but people only use some of it? I am thinking to major in programming and i might choose java to learn unless someone here can suggest a better one, and i have also been eying c++... I really don't know what to learn. Anyone here learning any programming lang.? Suggestions? Advise? Thanks!

item.title: Java? Rsps?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Alec_, post:3, topic:445771”][quote author=t4 link=topic=548036.msg4024376#msg4024376 date=1340230049]
???
[/quote]

he implied that you were a member of mscp, not mitb

you can take intro level university courses like BASICS OF OOP (which will cover an OOP language such as Python, Java, or C# and the like) or a community college course such as JAVA 101 which will just teach you the basics of Java.

you wouldn’t major in basics of oop or java 101, though.[/quote]
okay && duh

Read full topic

item.title: Java? Rsps?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Alec_, post:2, topic:445771”][quote author=Ruby link=topic=548036.msg4021650#msg4021650 date=1340053720]
Not gonna lie, I’ve never heard of you in my life and you just called one of the most respected users of this forum an idiot?
[/quote]

Not gonna lie, I’ve never heard of you in my life and you just called one of the most respected users of this forum an idiot?
one of the most respected users
most respected user
ha[/quote]
???

[quote=“Alec_, post:2, topic:445771”]@op what did you mean by all/some of java?..
also, I’m sure you can find a course on programming in college, there are obviously comp science courses but as t4 said; those classes teach computer science.[/quote]
you can take intro level university courses like BASICS OF OOP (which will cover an OOP language such as Python, Java, or C# and the like) or a community college course such as JAVA 101 which will just teach you the basics of Java.

Read full topic

item.title: Java? Rsps?
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

t4 is right. This is an example for computer science major requirements at Stony Brook University (a school I’m looking at going to).

[code]GENERAL REQUIREMENTS
At least two of the courses under the upper-division elective requirement below must be completed at Stony Brook.
Completion of the major requires approximately 80 credits.
All courses in the major must be taken for a letter grade
All courses in the major must be completed with a grade of C or higher.
REQUIRED INTRODUCTORY COURSES
CSE 114 Computer Science I
CSE 214 Computer Science II
CSE 215 Foundations of Computer Science
CSE 219 Computer Science III
CSE 220 Computer Organization
REQUIRED ADVANCED COURSES
CSE 303 Introduction to the Theory of Computation and CSE 373 Analysis of Algorithms
CSE 308 Software Engineering
CSE 320 Computer Organization and Architecture
Three courses chosen from: CSE 304, CSE 305, CSE 306, CSE 307, CSE 310/346, CSE 328. The three courses must include CSE 305 or CSE 306
COMPUTER SCIENCE ELECTIVES
Three upper-division CSE electives. Technical electives do not include teaching practica (CSE 475), internships (CSE 488), the senior honors project (CSE 495, 496), and courses designed as non-technical in the course description (such as CSE 301).
OAMS 151, AMS 161 APPLIED CALCULAS I, II
Note: The following alternate calculus course sequences may be substituted for AMS 151, AMS 161 in major requirements or prerequisites: MAT 125, MAT 126, MAT 127, or MAT 131, MAT 132, or MAT 141, MAT 142 or MAT 171. Equivalency for MAT courses achieved through the Mathematics Placement Examination is accepted to meet MAT course requirements.
ONE OF THE FOLLOWING
MAT 211 Introduction to Linear Algebra
AMS 210 Applied Linear Algebra
AMS 326 Numerical Analysis
BOTH OF THE FOLLOWING
AMS 301 Finite Mathematical Structures
AMS 310 Survey of Probability and Statistics or AMS 311 Probability Theory or AMS 312 Mathematical Statistics
NATURAL SCIENCE REQUIREMENT
One of the following natural science sequences [Effective fall 2005]:
BIO 201, BIO 202, BIO 204 or BIO 201, BIO 203, BIO 204 or BIO 202, BIO 203, BIO 204 Fundamentals of Biology or CHE 131, CHE 132, CHE 133 or CHE 141, CHE 142, CHE 143 General Chemistry or PHY 131/PHY 133, PHY 132/PHY 134 or PHY 141, PHY 142 or PHY 125, PHY 126, PHY 127 Classical Physics
Four additional credits from the above natural science courses [Effective fall 2005]
These courses can be in biology, chemistry, or physics. Advanced natural science courses may be substituted with the prior approval of the Department of Computer Science.
PROFESSIONAL ETHICS
CSE 312 Legal, Social, and Ethical Issues in Information Systems
UPPER-DIVISION WRITING REQUIREMENT
CSE 300 Technical Communications
All degree candidates must demonstrate technical writing skills at a level that would be acceptable in an industrial setting. To satisfy the requirement, students must pass CSE 300, a course that requires the completion of various writing assign­ments, including at least one significant technical paper.

Note: All students are encouraged to discuss their program with an undergraduate advisor. In Requirement 2 above, CSE/ESE double majors may substitute ESE 440, ESE 441 Electrical Engineering Design I, II for CSE 308 Software Engineering provided that the design project contains a significant software component. Approval of the Department of Computer Science is required.

[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Java? Rsps?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:22, topic:445336”][quote author=t4 link=topic=548036.msg4021706#msg4021706 date=1340056733]

i don’t believe you can major ‘in programming’…
[/quote][quote author=imsuperman05 link=topic=548036.msg4021647#msg4021647 date=1340053645]
You can major in Computer Science.

What about that didn’t make sense

computer science isn’t simply programming… there’s a lot more to it.

It’s not programming, but once you learn how the computer works then you can basically program anything into it.

… yes, making logical circuits by burning out fuses and hard-wiring buses is what you would consider programming.
[/quote]No…
I’m not sure where you’re from, but where I live (America) the process of getting a Computer Science degree actually involves learning multiple languages as a requirement.[/quote]
I don’t know what educational standards you have in regards to Computer Science degrees, but there are no REQUIREMENTS as far as languages go. Concepts are 99% of the time ALWAYS the same in ANY language. Computer Science is about concepts of computing in the same vein as an Artistic degree is about concepts of art. Frell best says this in his post in this thread.

Read full topic

Bottom line…
This is a stupid fucking idea? [/quote]

because here in america.
we have everything.

item.title: Java? Rsps?
item.dc:creator: @asshole_rule asshole_rule
item.description:
@asshole_rule wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:21, topic:445336”][quote author=imsuperman05 link=topic=548036.msg4021688#msg4021688 date=1340056108]

i don’t believe you can major ‘in programming’…
[/quote][quote author=imsuperman05 link=topic=548036.msg4021647#msg4021647 date=1340053645]
You can major in Computer Science.

What about that didn’t make sense

computer science isn’t simply programming… there’s a lot more to it.

It’s not programming, but once you learn how the computer works then you can basically program anything into it.
[/quote]
… yes, making logical circuits by burning out fuses and hard-wiring buses is what you would consider programming.

My brother is a software engineer and is studying C++ and says it’s a bitch, he has a little java back round from 1 high school class he’s taken. He prefers Java, but is sticking with C++ for some crazy reason.

Morale of the story, I’d go with java.

A real Computer Scientist or worthy Software Engineer (which is a joke of a major usually) doesn’t study a language… Sure, they can have classes that utilize certain languages, but no real CS person just studies C++, Java, what have you.

Every language has its use, some tasks are easier in some and harder in others.[/quote]

Cool. He studies C++…

Read full topic

item.title: Java? Rsps?
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

[quote=“matiasmunk, post:9, topic:445336”][quote author=t4 link=topic=548036.msg4018871#msg4018871 date=1339867970]

Don’t learn C++, learn C. :rolleyes:
All the advice I can give.

it’s a real shame your advice is fucking stupid and has no real backing.

It’s not.
C++ has more features & is more stable.

incorrect. if you’ve never used either or know anything about the specifics of the language (benefits and pitfalls, please don’t bother posting)
[/quote]

If I’ve never used it? Lol, I know C & C++ idiot, or else I wouldn’t post here :facepalm:
I’m just giving you my opinion = C++ is more stable.[/quote]

Not gonna lie, I’ve never heard of you in my life and you just called one of the most respected users of this forum an idiot?

Read full topic

item.title: Java? Rsps?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“matiasmunk, post:9, topic:445336”][quote author=t4 link=topic=548036.msg4018871#msg4018871 date=1339867970]

Don’t learn C++, learn C. :rolleyes:
All the advice I can give.

it’s a real shame your advice is fucking stupid and has no real backing.

It’s not.
C++ has more features & is more stable.

incorrect. if you’ve never used either or know anything about the specifics of the language (benefits and pitfalls, please don’t bother posting)
[/quote]

If I’ve never used it? Lol, I know C & C++ idiot, or else I wouldn’t post here :facepalm:
I’m just giving you my opinion = C++ is more stable.[/quote]
more stable? are you mad? both C and C++ both have ISO standards and are both stable languages. if anything, C is ‘more stable’ than C++ in the difference of age and maturity.

sure, you may know some C++ syntax, but your opinion (that also doesn’t have any supporting evidence) clearly reveals you’re not very familiar with the overall concepts of the language or understand its relationship to C.

Read full topic
